My little darling only helped out with cash for a bit. She said, “I can’t come see you too often. Maybe after dark when no one’s watching.” 

So, I took a nap after dinner, and guess what? Katerina Ivanovna, who had a huge fight with our landlady Amalia Fyodorovna just a week ago, actually invited her in for coffee. They sat together for two hours, whispering. 

“Did you hear? Semyon Zaharovitch is back in service and getting paid again,” she said. “He even went to his boss, and the boss came out to meet him, making everyone else wait. He took Semyon Zaharovitch by the hand and led him into his office.” 

“Did you hear that?” she repeated. The boss said, “Semyon Zaharovitch, I remember your past work. Even with your little issues, I trust you now since we’ve struggled without you.” 

Let me tell you, she totally made that up. And not just for fun—she really believes it! She entertains herself with her own stories, I swear! I don’t blame her for it, though. 

Six days ago, when I brought her my first paycheck—twenty-three roubles and forty kopecks—she called me her “poppet.” “My little poppet,” she said. And when we were alone, you know? You wouldn’t think I was much to look at or a great husband, right? But she pinched my cheek and said, “My little poppet.” 🥰

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Marmeladov recounts his struggles and the delusions of his wife, Katerina Ivanovna, as he reflects on their life and his recent earnings.
